title: 107_hr4083
content: The "Corporate Responsibility Act of 2002" may require disgorgement. The Securities and Exchange Commission will prescribe regulations for disgorgement of various financial gains obtained through misconduct by officers or directors of an issuer. This applies to false or misleading financial statements filed during a fiscal year. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include additional disgorgement authority in actions brought by the Commission against individuals for misconduct related to false or misleading financial statements. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to allow for disgorgement of benefits received by individuals who engage in, cause, or aid violations of securities laws. This includes disgorging salary, commissions, fees, bonuses, options, profits, and avoided losses. SEC. 3. CEO AND CFO ACCOUNTABILITY FOR DISCLOSURE. The Securities and Exchange Commission will require company executives to certify the accuracy of financial reports filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The signing officers are responsible for establishing and maintaining internal controls to ensure material information is known to them, and they have evaluated the effectiveness of these controls within 90 days prior to the report. The signing officers must disclose significant deficiencies in internal controls and any fraud involving management or employees to the issuer's auditors and audit committee. The signing officers must disclose significant deficiencies in internal controls, any fraud involving management or employees, and indicate any changes in internal controls subsequent to their evaluation. The rules required by this section must be effective within 30 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF UNFIT CORPORATE OFFICERS. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF UNFIT CORPORATE OFFICERS. Amendments are made to the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to replace "substantial unfitness" with "unfitness" in judicial proceedings. In administrative proceedings, the SEC is granted authority to prohibit individuals from serving as officers or directors in cease-and-desist proceedings. The SEC has the authority to prohibit individuals from serving as officers or directors of any issuer if their conduct demonstrates unfitness, as stated in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. This can be done unconditionally, permanently, or for a specified period of time. The SEC can ban individuals who violate securities regulations from being officers or directors of registered issuers if their conduct shows they are unfit for the role.
